content.raw:
Interesting... I expected success to be false, but this maybe by design. @chapulina, @iche033, is it correct to expect `success` even if the entity doesn't exist?

Also, I spoke with Louise and she told me it would be hard to determine whether the model still exists in the simulation. So I am now of the opinion that your original code is good enough. Thanks for exploring the issue.
content.html:

Also, I spoke with Louise and she told me it would be hard to determine whether the model still exists in the simulation. So I am now of the opinion that your original code is good enough. Thanks for exploring the issue.

content.raw:
The `success` returned here probably just means the server received the request, but it has nothing to do with whether the deletion was actually performed successfully.

It's complicated at the moment to get feedback on whether the deletion was successful or not. This should be addressed when we start using ign-transport for deletion requests. Gzclient and Gzweb listen to their own `entity_delete` requests as "feedback" about a model's deletion.
content.html:
The success returned here probably just means the server received the request, but it has nothing to do with whether the deletion was actually performed successfully.

It's complicated at the moment to get feedback on whether the deletion was successful or not. This should be addressed when we start using ign-transport for deletion requests. Gzclient and Gzweb listen to their own entity_delete requests as "feedback" about a model's deletion.

content.raw: Can you please add a "deleteEntity" on the Gazebo object in index.js. This will allow to call gazebo.deleteEntity instead of gazebo.sim.deleteEntity. Please also add documentation for the call, because we will generate jsdoc type (markdown) documentation for gazebojs in the repo (soon).

content.raw:
This line looks redundant. There is already a spawn at line 31.
Also, it looks like there should be a 

```
#!python

gazebo.spawn

```
It would be great if you could add it in index.js  and replace the `gazebo.sim.spawn` with `gazebo.spawn`

The reason to "hide" the sim object is that it is the C++ addon itself, and gazebo is a pure javascript object. Hidding the C++ addon makes it easier to provide advanced javascript features that are hard to implement in C++ (promises, exceptions, callbacks) or add features like logging before each call.

The reason to "hide" the sim object is that it is the C++ addon itself, and gazebo is a pure javascript object. Hidding the C++ addon makes it easier to provide advanced javascript features that are hard to implement in C++ (promises, exceptions, callbacks) or add features like logging before each call.
